debateinfo: TRADE PRACTICES AMENDMENT (INDUSTRY ACCESS CODES) BILL 1997
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr LATHAM
content: —The member for Corangamite will find, in my case, that consistency is a virtue. I am speaking in favour of the competition reforms we introduced in government and which remain in the national interest. The principle is very sound. In the case of infrastructure characterised by monopoly or oligopoly features you should not need to own an electricity power station to retail electricity and you should not need to own a gas pipeline to retail gas. I would also argue that, in the petrol industry, you should not need to own and have tied access arrangements to a petroleum terminal to be an effective retailer in that particular industry.So the concept of downstream access makes sense. It allows a competitive retail, and even a competitive wholesale, market to be established in industries which are essentially vertically integrated and have monopoly and oligopoly characteristics. These are basically infrastructure industries.The bill brought into the Senate is something that we have no problem with. The idea of an industry‐wide access code seems to make some sense. The problem the Labor Party has with the provision concerns the amendments that the government put to its own bill in the Senate. They are amendments which minimise the public consultation process. They allow the ACCC, without any amount of public notification or public consultation, to determine undertakings after the industry‐wide code has been established.I believe, in principle—and I know I am supported throughout wide sectors of private industry in Australia—that the undertakings power and discretion of the ACCC needs to be treated with caution. It is not necessarily good public policy to expand the undertakings capacity of the ACCC without public consultation when there are, within the boardrooms of Australia and in the public arena, a whole set of concerns about the way in which the ACCC has been exercising those powers in the past.I will offer a few examples. The most pertinent is the decision that was made with regard to the merger between Ampol and Caltex. Ampol was allowed to merge with Caltex on the basis that they would divest certain terminal facilities and would provide certain access undertakings to their terminals, but it left an inconsistency in the industry structure. Ampol‐Caltex has divested and Ampol‐Caltex provides some limited access, but BP, Shell and Mobil do not.Now we have an aggressive campaign by Ampol‐Caltex to try to apply those same standards of access to its three main competitors: BP, Shell and Ampol. It is not the role of the competition regulator, like the ACCC, to set one standard of regulations for one company in an industry and have the other three major competitors under a different set of industry rules. But that was the net effect of the ACCC discretionary use of the undertakings power in that industry. This was an instance of industry moulding—industry moulding in the case of petrol, the world according to Fels—rather than strict industry regulation where the regulations apply equally across the entire industry.That has been a concern to participants in the petrol industry. It has been a concern remarked on by academics around Australia and, from my discussions, a concern with members on both sides of this parliament. Why should Ampol‐Caltex have a different set of industry regulations and rules applied to it compared with its three major competitors? If undertakings are to be applied, they should be in the name of fair competition. They should be in the name of equal regulation right across all parts of a particular industry. This was a case of industry moulding.The ACCC subsequently produced a report on petrol that used the Ampol‐Caltex merger as an argument for retail market entry in the industry. You get more competition because Ampol‐Caltex has opened up its terminals, and with extra imports of petrol this could facilitate new retail players in the market. This is an instance where, clearly, the ACCC decision or undertakings in terms of the Ampol and Caltex merger were framed to accommodate the matters ACCC had in mind for its petrol report to the federal government. It was an instance where it was moulding this industry according to its own priorities; moulding the industry in its own image, rather than setting regulations across the board that apply equally and fairly to all competitors in the industry. I am an opponent of industry moulding.I am an opponent of the way in which the ACCC used its undertakings power in the Ampol‐Caltex case. If it was good enough for Ampol‐Caltex to have terminal access imposed upon it by the ACCC, it should be good enough for BP and it should be good enough for Shell and Mobil. That is the best way to cleanly regulate an industry, instead of moulding it, knowing that there is a report coming up to be used in a fashion consistent with the dirty regulation of the petrol industry.That is the first instance that has been raised. I noticed recently, again, criticisms of the ACCC in these matters. Mr John David, the executive chairman of the wholesaler and grocery retailer, Davids, has accused the ACCC of moving the goalposts to allow Woolworths Ltd into the wholesaling market. I will quote from the Australian Financial Review of 12 March:Mr David told reporters yesterday the ACCC had previously ruled that wholesaling and retailing were the one market for the purposes of making a decision on Davids acquisition of QIW and Composite Buyers, and was now defining the markets as separate.This is another instance where the ACCC inconsistently is trying to mould industry outcomes—in this case to the benefit of Woolworths—instead of operating as a clean and consistent regulator that applies the same standard across time and the same standard to all participants in a particular industry.That is why the Labor Party is concerned about the governments decision to open up further powers of undertaking by the ACCC in this legislation without public consultation. If the industry code is to be altered by way of the ACCCs discretionary use of undertakings, why should the public not be involved in that process? Why should not all those industry players particularly affected by that decision be notified, be able to make submissions and, moreover, beyond that, why should they not have some power of appeal? Why should there not be a third party appeal right in these particular instances? The parliament is placing too much power and authority in the ACCC when on its track record it is not acting as a clean industry regulator, consistent across time and across the board with market participants. It is acting as a dirty regulator, moulding these industries according to its own priorities.I express that concern in relation to the bill. I further point out to the Main Committee, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the Labor Party has amendments to move in detail. We seek to use this Trade Practices Amendment (Industry Access Codes) Bill 1996 to apply part 3A access—the downstream access regime—to petroleum terminals. These were amendments that were also moved in the Senate and defeated on the casting vote of Senator Colston in that chamber. The Labor Party will be persevering with those amendments, once the consideration in detail is referred to the main chamber of the House of Representatives.It is a debate that is, of course, relevant to this bill but it does not detract from the support that we can lend to the concept of general industry access code approval processes. It uses this bill, and the parliaments consideration of part 3A of the Trade Practices Act, as a vehicle for establishing downstream access in the petroleum industry. I see no difference between the structure of electricity, for instance, an homogenous product with a vertically integrated structure, and downstream access applying there. There is no difference to the way in which downstream access can be applied in petrol—again, an undifferentiated product with a vertical industry structure.It is interesting to note in that earlier decision by the ACCC that, for the purpose of groceries, retailing and wholesaling are part of the one market. If that standard were applied in petrol, why did the ACCC not recommend some vertical separation? Why are they willing to tolerate the situation where the major oil companies in Australia control the exploration, refining, distribution and retailing through the vertical control and ownership structure in this industry? Why did the ACCC not recommend some element of vertical separation? Why did they not recommend in their report last year the amendments that I will be moving in the Main Chamber; that is, to place the petroleum industry on the access regime, to give every single service station operator and distributor in Australia his or her chance to shop around for the cheapest wholesale petrol?Those particular concepts, that particular use of part 3A of the Trade Practices Act, is becoming more relevant by the day. I refer to the Daily Liberal , the newspaper in Dubbo where Woolworths has entered the industry. This is a report from last week, 14 March. It says that plunging petrol prices have Dubbos fuel retailers on the brink of turmoil. One couple is netting as little as $300 for a combined total of 140 hours per weeks work, slightly more than $2 per hour. Because Woolworths has got access to cheaper wholesale petrol than the oil majors will provide to their retailers, the whole generation of small businesses around country New South Wales—and it will happen right around the country—is being wiped out because of unfair competition.Why should Woolworths have access to cheaper wholesale petrol that is being denied to existing service stations in country towns? There is a real risk right around the country that these country towns will become planet Woolworths. Woolworths will do all the petrol retailing, all the pharmacy work, all the newsagency work, and all the groceries. Every country town will become nothing more than a planet Woolworths where all other business interests are orbiting around the main business interest.That is not healthy at all. There is a legitimate argument to place the petrol industry on the access regime so that these retailers in Dubbo and beyond can access the same cheap wholesale petrol. I am getting into National Party language, arent I? Someone has got to represent them effectively and it will be the Labor Party that says that those retailers in Dubbo should have the same access to cheaper wholesale petrol that Woolworths enjoys.For a government that talks about industry, entrepreneurialism and small business effort, how can they just sit there and grin at the prospect of small business—the Prime Ministers family once ran a business like this—netting as little as $300 for a combined total of 140 hours of work, all because the government will not accept the principle of fair wholesale competition in the petrol industry? All the government needs to do is tick off the Labor Party amendments in the Main Chamber and these people in Dubbo and hundreds like them around New South Wales and, indeed, the entire country, will have fair access to wholesale petrol and a fair chance to compete against Woolworths.

Speaker: N/A

name: Mr Vaile
content: —You were in government from 1983 to 1996. You could have done it then.
debateinfo: TRADE PRACTICES AMENDMENT (INDUSTRY ACCESS CODES) BILL 1997
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr LATHAM
content: —We are doing it now. In government, we commissioned the ACCC to deliver a report. You should always wait for the findings of reports and the findings were inadequate. That is why we are acting now and you should support us. That is the truth of it. It is an opportunity for the National Party to do more than just talk platitudes of lower petrol prices and fair competition in the bush. It is their way to write it into the laws of the Commonwealth.I look forward to that debate in the main chamber. We had a very good debate, as I mentioned, in the Senate on these matters. The National Party, particularly the Queenslanders, went missing. Senator Boswell from Queensland, who talks the language of assisting small petrol retailers around his state, voted against the concept of putting the petrol industry on the access regime. He opposed the means by which these small businesses, these small petrol retailers, can have a fair crack at competition with the likes of Woolworths. If this government does not stand for something better than $300 total income for 140 hours of small business work, then something has gone wrong. There is a big gap between its rhetoric and the way in which its policies are playing out around regional Australia. So the Labor Party will be representing the interests of these people. We will be trying to write their interests into the law of the Commonwealth using this bill and amendments to the Trade Practices Act to put petrol on part 3A access.Debate (on motion by Mr Vaile ) adjourned.Main Committee adjourned at 1 p.m.N/AN/A

name: Mr McClelland
content: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 10 February 1997:(1) Will the Government remove the means test exemption of assets held in superannuation and roll over funds; if so, when.(2) If the exemption is to be removed, from which class of persons will it be removed.(3) Will the exemption be retained for persons who are unable to access their superannuation savings; if so, what criteria will be applied.
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr Ruddock
content: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable members question:(1) In the 1996 Federal Budget the Government announced that the Social Security income test and asset test exemption for superannuation assets of customers who are aged less than Age Pension age will be removed from 20 September 1997 if certain conditions are met. The conditions are that the customer has been in receipt of a pension or allowance income support payment for a total of 39 weeks after reaching the age of 55.The income test and asset test exemption for superannuation assets of all other customers aged less than Age Pension age will continue.Legislation for this measure has been passed by Parliament, and it will come into effect from 20 September 1997.(2) See answer to (1).(3) Where a customer genuinely cannot access a superannuation asset, I have the legislative power to exempt the asset from assessment under the income test. I have assured the Parliament that where an affected person is working, and hence is unable to gain access to superannuation assets, the power to exempt those assets will be exercised. I also have under consideration other situations where exemptions may be warranted.The existing asset test hardship legislative provisions are also available to affected persons in circumstances where the exemption power was not exercised.

name: Mr Filing
content: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 4 March 1997:(1) Is the double orphan pension indexed; if not, why not.(2) Is it a fact that persons called on to care for orphaned children may have different lifestyles and levels of income.(3) Are senior citizens and pensioners who rely solely on payments from the Ministers Department paid the same sum to look after orphaned children as families with infrastructure in place to care for other children; if so, why.(4) Will the Minister adjust the double orphan pension to take into account the additional needs of varying groups called on to care for orphans.
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr Ruddock
content: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable members question:(1) Yes.(2) Yes.(3) Double Orphan Pension is paid at the same rate of $37.50 per fortnight to all carers of orphans. This is because it is intended to address any additional financial strain of caring for an orphan child. Most recipients of Double Orphan Pension are also receiving Family Payment which aims to provide help with the ongoing costs of raising children. Pensioners with dependent children receive Family Payment at the maximum rate (which is $124.90 a fortnight for each child aged 13‐15 years and $96.00 a fortnight for each child under 13). Other supplements and assistance are available according to the carers circumstances such as Guardian Allowance for sole parents. The Government is also providing additional assistance to families through the Family Tax Initiative.(4) The view of the Government is that the needs of different groups are addressed through the existing system of assistance. However, as with all pensions, the Government will be keeping the appropriateness and adequacy of payments under review.N/A
